caption.text: Model performance measures for cumulative dose threshold

legend.text: The C-index measures the modelâ€™s rank discrimination (ie, the ability of the model to correctly rank subjects), with 1 being perfect discrimination and 0.5 indicating a coin toss model. The calibration error measures how far apart in percentage points model-based predictions are from true predictions, as in a calibration curve, for each ordinal model cut point. The mean absolute calibration error is the absolute prediction error averaged across all predictions made, with an analogous definition for the 90th percentile of absolute prediction error. In each case, the smaller the error, the better.

statement.text: The Mean of the Absolute calibration error of 0.1 g is the lowest for IgG 4 to peanut.
The Mean Absolute calibration error of 0.1 g for BAT is 0.01.
Model Multivariable for C-Index has the value of 9.981.
Model IgG4 to peanut for C-Index has the highest value, 7.565
Model Multivariable for C-Index has the highest value, 0.981.
Mean absolute calibration error of 0.1 g for IgE to peanut has the highest value, 4
Mean Absolute calibration error of 0.1 g for Multivariable has the lowest value, 1.6.
The nomogram in Fig 4 , B depicts this multivariable model and can be used to make predictions of threshold of future reactions during PA testing.
A similar nomogram without BAT is shown in Fig E11 (in this articleAos Online Repository at www.jacionline.org ).

caption.text: Model performance measures for reaction severity

legend.text: The C-index measures the modelâ€™s rank discrimination (ie, the ability of the model to correctly rank subjects), with 1 being perfect discrimination and 0.5 indicating a coin toss model. The calibration error measures how far apart in percentage points model-based predictions are from true predictions, as in a calibration curve, for each ordinal model cut point. The mean absolute calibration error is the absolute prediction error averaged across all predictions made, with an analogous definition for the 90th percentile of absolute prediction error. In each case, the smaller the error, the better.

statement.text: There are two models present in the table.
Modesl Ara h 2Aispecific IgE and BAT have different C-Index values.
Model SPT does not have C-Index value
Multivariable (BAT) and SPT has same mean moderate or higher absolute calibration error.
There are seven models present in the table.
Models Ara h 2Aispecific IgE and BAT have the same C-Index values.
90th percentile Moderate or higher absolute calibration error is different for every model.
IgE to peanut has the highest mean severe/life-threatening absolute calibration error.
We performed internal validation of these models by using the bootstrap to correct for the bias of using the same data to fit and validate the model.

Although the performance of both multivariate models was good ( Table III ), on the basis of calibration, the model including the BAT more accurately predicted the probability of severe or life-threatening reactions than did either the model without the BAT or the individual tests.

An additional 123 subjects were eligible for the BAT but were not tested for logistic reasons (see Tables E7 and E8 in this articleAos Online Repository at www.jacionline.org ).
On the BAT, in 93 samples (13.1%) basophils did not react to the IgE-mediated positive controls and were excluded from statistical analyses.

caption.text: Optimal cutoffs to classify subjects at high-risk for developing severe allergic reactions and reacting to a low dose (â‰¤0.1 gs) of peanut protein during oral peanut challenge

legend.text:
Severity was assessed according to the Common Terminology Criteria for Adverse Events scale. Optimal cutoffs were determined on the basis of the Youden index, which is the distance between the point of inflection of the receiver operator characteristic curve and the reference line (see the in this articleâ€™s Online Repository at
www.jacionline.org
). Sensitivity, specificity, PPV, and NPV with 95% CIs are indicated for each cutoff.
NPV
, Negative predictive value;
PPV
, positive predictive value.

cell.text: Threshold â‰¤0.1 g vs >0.1 g of peanut protein

statement.text: They have ten different parameters.

Ara h 2 Ai specific IgE (kU/L) Sensitivity is lower in Severe versus nonsevere allergic reactions than Threshold a0.1 g vs >0.1 g of peanut protein.
Peanut SPT (mm) Cutoff is higher in Severe versus nonsevere allergic reactions than Threshold a0.1 g vs >0.1 g of peanut protein.
They have six different parameters.
BAT (% of CD63 + basophils) Cutoff is higher in Severe versus nonsevere allergic reactions than Threshold a0.1 g vs >0.1 g of peanut protein.
Ara h 2 Ai specific IgE (kU/L) Sensitivity is higher in Severe versus nonsevere allergic reactions than Threshold a0.1 g vs >0.1 g of peanut protein.
IgG4/IgE r atio NPV is higher in Severe versus nonsevere allergic reactions than Threshold a0.1 g vs >0.1 g of peanut protein.

Fig E7 shows the estimated proportion of participants who remain reaction-free as a function of cumulative peanut dose and reinforces the concept that the higher the proportion of activated basophils, the lower the dose of peanut protein to which patients react during OFC.

With use of the receiver operator characteristic curve analyses, the optimal cutoffs for the SPT, level of Ara h 2Aispecific IgE, and IgG4/IgE ratios also had a very good performance in identifying patients with a cumulative threshold dose of 0.1 g or lower ( Table II ).
